Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A client quietly shares a private concern while filling out forms at the check-in table.
Story: I was just finishing my volunteer shift at the community center when I saw Mark, an acquaintance from my old book club, waving at me from across the lobby. He looked a bit frazzled and, after a quick hello, asked if I could help him move some boxes to his new apartment later that afternoon. I knew he didn’t have many friends in town, and I could tell he really needed the help. As I was about to answer, a client approached my check-in table, her voice barely above a whisper as she confided a personal concern about her living situation. She asked me to keep it between us, her eyes pleading for reassurance. I nodded, feeling the weight of her trust. Now, I was torn—Mark expected the easy camaraderie of acquaintances, a simple favor, while my role as a volunteer demanded strict confidentiality and undivided attention to those I served. I could feel the tension building inside me, unsure how to balance the pull of friendship with the responsibility of privacy.
